title: Oracle, Apple, Lucid: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today; Oracle is slipping after an earnings report; Apple is edging up ahead of its iPhone reveal event
text:
* Oracle slipped nearly 2% in premarket trading after the enterprise software giant reported quarterly revenue that came in below Wall Street's estimates on Monday after hours.

* Apple is set to reveal its latest lineup of iPhones in a virtual talk led by CEO Tim Cook on Tuesday. Apple shares are up 0.4% ahead of the event. Watch it here.

* Electric vehicle maker Lucid Group fell over 4%. An equity research analyst at Morgan Stanley initiated coverage of the company at underweight.

* Oil explorers and oilfield services companies are edging up as crude prices rise for a third straight day with the Brent benchmark reaching the highest level since July. Halliburtonadded 1.3%, Occidental Petroleum rose 1.2% and Devon Energy advanced 1.3%.

* U.S.-listed shares of Chinese tech giants slid for a second day as Beijing continued its crackdown. Gaming giant NetEase lost 2.4%, video sharing platform Bilibili slipped 2.3% and search engine Baidu fell 2%.

* Opendoor Technologies, an online residential real-estate company, retreated 4.3% after it said one of its stockholders is selling 28 million shares in a secondary offering.

* Bitcoin rose 1.6% compared to its level at 5 p.m. Monday, trading around $45,900. The cryptocurrency stabilized after whipsawing the previous day after a fake press release said that Walmart would allow payments using litecoin, another type of digital currency. Litecoin retreated close to 2%.

* Crypto trading platform Coinbase shares rose 1.3% premarket after media reports the company was in the market to issue more than $1 billion in bonds to fuel its growth.

Chart of the Day

* Shares of uranium mining companies surged as retail traders from Reddit's WallStreetBets forum focused their energies on the rallying radioactive metal. Companies tied to uranium in Australia and the U.K. powered higher Monday, while shares of U.S.-listed companies also rose.
